Package: io.vertx.ext.web

[Java] Interface RoutingContext

  • Represents the context for the handling of a request in Vert.x-Web.

    A new instance is created for each HTTP request that is received in the io.vertx.ext.web.Router#accept(io.vertx.core.http.HttpServerRequest) of the router.

    The same instance is passed to any matching request or failure handlers during the routing of the request or failure.

    The context provides access to the io.vertx.core.http.HttpServerRequest and io.vertx.core.http.HttpServerResponse and allows you to maintain arbitrary data that lives for the lifetime of the context. Contexts are discarded once they have been routed to the handler for the request.

    The context also provides access to the Session, cookies and body for the request, given the correct handlers in the application.

    Authors:
    Tim Fox

    • Method Detail

      • public int addBodyEndHandler(Handler<Void> handler)

        Add a handler that will be called just before the response body has been completely written. This gives you a hook where you can write any extra data to the response before it has ended when it will be too late.

        Returns:
        the id of the handler. This can be used if you later want to remove the handler.
        Parameters:
        handler - the handler

      • @Fluent public RoutingContext addCookie(Cookie cookie)

        Add a cookie. This will be sent back to the client in the response. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.CookieHandler for this to work.

        Returns:
        a reference to this, so the API can be used fluently
        Parameters:
        cookie - the cookie

      • public int addHeadersEndHandler(Handler<Future> handler)

        Add a handler that will be called just before headers are written to the response. This gives you a hook where you can write any extra headers before the response has been written when it will be too late. The handler will be passed a future, when you've completed the work you want to do you should complete (or fail) the future. This can be done after the handler has returned.

        Returns:
        the id of the handler. This can be used if you later want to remove the handler.
        Parameters:
        handler - the handler

      • public int cookieCount()

        Returns:
        the number of cookies. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.CookieHandler for this to work.

      • public Set<Cookie> cookies()

        Returns:
        a set of all the cookies. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.CookieHandler for this to be populated.

      • public Route currentRoute()

        Returns:
        the current route this context is being routed through.

      • @GenIgnore public Map<String, Object> data()

        Returns:
        all the context data as a map

      • public void fail(int statusCode)

        Fail the context with the specified status code.

        This will cause the router to route the context to any matching failure handlers for the request. If no failure handlers match a default failure response will be sent.

        Parameters:
        statusCode - the HTTP status code

      • @GenIgnore public void fail(Throwable throwable)

        Fail the context with the specified throwable.

        This will cause the router to route the context to any matching failure handlers for the request. If no failure handlers match a default failure response with status code 500 will be sent.

        Parameters:
        throwable - a throwable representing the failure

      • public boolean failed()

        Returns:
        true if the context is being routed to failure handlers.

      • @GenIgnore @CacheReturn public Throwable failure()

        If the context is being routed to failure handlers after a failure has been triggered by calling fail(Throwable) then this will return that throwable. It can be used by failure handlers to render a response, e.g. create a failure response page.

        Returns:
        the throwable used when signalling failure

      • public Set<FileUpload> fileUploads()

        Returns:
        a set of fileuploads (if any) for the request. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.BodyHandler for this to work.

      • public T get(String key)

        Get some data from the context. The data is available in any handlers that receive the context.

        throws:
        java.lang.ClassCastException if the data is not of the expected type
        Returns:
        the data
        Parameters:
        key - the key for the data
        - the type of the data

      • public String getAcceptableContentType()

        If the route specifies produces matches, e.g. produces `text/html` and `text/plain`, and the `accept` header matches one or more of these then this returns the most acceptable match.

        Returns:
        the most acceptable content type.

      • public Buffer getBody()

        Returns:
        Get the entire HTTP request body as a io.vertx.core.buffer.Buffer. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.BodyHandler for this to be populated.

      • public JsonObject getBodyAsJson()

        Returns:
        Get the entire HTTP request body as a io.vertx.core.json.JsonObject. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.BodyHandler for this to be populated.

      • public String getBodyAsString()

        Returns:
        the entire HTTP request body as a string, assuming UTF-8 encoding. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.BodyHandler for this to be populated.

      • public String getBodyAsString(String encoding)

        Get the entire HTTP request body as a string, assuming the specified encoding. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.BodyHandler for this to be populated.

        Returns:
        the body
        Parameters:
        encoding - the encoding, e.g. "UTF-16"

      • public Cookie getCookie(String name)

        Get the cookie with the specified name. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.CookieHandler for this to work.

        Returns:
        the cookie
        Parameters:
        name - the cookie name

      • public String mountPoint()

        Returns:
        the mount point for this router. It will be null for a top level router. For a sub-router it will be the path at which the subrouter was mounted.

      • public void next()

        Tell the router to route this context to the next matching route (if any). This method, if called, does not need to be called during the execution of the handler, it can be called some arbitrary time later, if required.

        If next is not called for a handler then the handler should make sure it ends the response or no response will be sent.

      • public String normalisedPath()

        Return the normalised path for the request.

        The normalised path is where the URI path has been decoded, i.e. any unicode or other illegal URL characters that were encoded in the original URL with `%` will be returned to their original form. E.g. `%20` will revert to a space. Also `+` reverts to a space in a query.

        The normalised path will also not contain any `..` character sequences to prevent resources being accessed outside of the permitted area.

        It's recommended to always use the normalised path as opposed to io.vertx.core.http.HttpServerRequest#path() if accessing server resources requested by a client.

        Returns:
        the normalised path

      • @Fluent public RoutingContext put(String key, Object obj)

        Put some arbitrary data in the context. This will be available in any handlers that receive the context.

        Returns:
        a reference to this, so the API can be used fluently
        Parameters:
        key - the key for the data
        obj - the data

      • public boolean removeBodyEndHandler(int handlerID)

        Remove a body end handler

        Returns:
        true if the handler existed and was removed, false otherwise
        Parameters:
        handlerID - the id as returned from RoutingContext.addBodyEndHandler.

      • public Cookie removeCookie(String name)

        Remove a cookie. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.CookieHandler for this to work.

        Returns:
        the cookie, if it existed, or null
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the cookie

      • public boolean removeHeadersEndHandler(int handlerID)

        Remove a headers end handler

        Returns:
        true if the handler existed and was removed, false otherwise
        Parameters:
        handlerID - the id as returned from RoutingContext.addHeadersEndHandler.

      • @CacheReturn public HttpServerRequest request()

        Returns:
        the HTTP request object

      • @CacheReturn public HttpServerResponse response()

        Returns:
        the HTTP response object

      • public Session session()

        Get the session. The context must have first been routed to a io.vertx.ext.web.handler.SessionHandler for this to be populated. Sessions live for a browser session, and are maintained by session cookies.

        Returns:
        the session.

      • public void setAcceptableContentType(String contentType)

        Set the acceptable content type. Used by

        Parameters:
        contentType - the content type

      • public void setBody(Buffer body)

        Set the body. Used by the io.vertx.ext.web.handler.BodyHandler. You will not normally call this method.

        Parameters:
        body - the body

      • public void setSession(Session session)

        Set the session. Used by the io.vertx.ext.web.handler.SessionHandler. You will not normally call this method.

        Parameters:
        session - the session

      • public void setUser(User user)

        Set the user. Usually used by auth handlers to inject a User. You will not normally call this method.

        Parameters:
        user - the user

      • @CacheReturn public int statusCode()

        If the context is being routed to failure handlers after a failure has been triggered by calling fail(int) then this will return that status code. It can be used by failure handlers to render a response, e.g. create a failure response page.

        Returns:
        the status code used when signalling failure

      • public User user()

        Get the authenticated user (if any). This will usually be injected by an auth handler if authentication if successful.

        Returns:
        the user, or null if the current user is not authenticated.

      • public Vertx vertx()

        Returns:
        the Vert.x instance associated to the initiating io.vertx.ext.web.Router for this context
